div.p: The process begins when an organisation needs to certify their health system with the EEHRxF. This step involves the initiation of a formal certification process aimed at ensuring that health systems or applications adhere to the standards and policies defined within the European Electronic Health Record Exchange Format (EEHRxF). At this stage, a decision arises, posing the question: "What is the level of certification needed?" The applicant must decide between two available paths based on the desired rigor of the certification: Level One (Self-assessment) or Level Two (Third-party assessment).

p.em: Disclaimer: The current process to attain the xShare Industry Label and demonstrante compliance with the EEHRxF is currently under development and this process is likely to go trough alterations.

ol.li: Step 1: Register on the EEHRxF Policy and Standards Hub website. This portal (not online yet) serves as the entry point for applicants seeking self-certification. The website (https://ehr-exchange-format.eu/) will provide comprehensive resources, including policy documents, technical specifications, and the self-assessment tool.

Step 2: Access the xShare Industry Label self-assessment tool (https://ehds-testing.ihe-europe.net/). In the Gazelle environment, a testing tool with a checklist for EEHRxF certification criteria will guide organisations through the process.
Step 3: Upload relevant data into the system to evaluate compliance with EEHRxF standards based on the xShare Industry Label criteria.
Step 4: The self-assessment tool evaluates the submitted data based on predefined criteria (a checklist) and provides preliminary feedback about compliance status.

div.p: Decision Point: "Is the uploaded data compliant with EEHRxF certification criteria?"

ol.li: Receive positive preliminary feedback and comments.
Proceed to the quality criteria evaluation phase.
Decision Point: "Does the system comply with the quality assessment criteria?"
If compliant: Receive a final positive assessment and certification.
If not compliant: Receive negative feedback and guidelines for improvement.

ul.li: Receive negative preliminary feedback and improvement guidelines.

ol.li: Step 1: The Member State-designated organisation responsible for overseeing the certification process receives the request from the Industry.
Step 2: Submit a formal request for certification, including documentation and payment, to the designated authority (e.g., TIC Salut in Catalonia).
Step 3: The authority acknowledges receipt of the request and associated payment.
Step 4: Relevant data is identified for assessment, including technical specifications and functional details.
Step 5: Provide data in an acceptable format (such as XML or Json) for submission into the assessment tool.
Step 6: Define priority data category validation format and mandatory requirements for compliance.
Step 7: Submit a declaration of conformity for analysis against EEHRxF standards.
Steps 8-10: Evaluate structure, functionality, and specific features using tools like Gazelle.
Step 11: Evaluate overall conformance, including the xShare Industry Label as an add-on.
Step 12: An assessment report is created to highlight any non-conformities.

div.p: Decision Point: "Has the system passed the evaluation criteria, including EEHRxF conformity?"

ul.li: If Yes: The authority provides the certification label, concluding the process successfully.
If No: The certification label is not issued, and a conformity report is provided with improvement recommendations.
